												At first glance Magicka will look like a fun button mashing experience to have with your friends. If you look further you will see that there is more enjoyment to experience from Magicka than you could ever see from the trailers and screenshots. Magicka has created something that no game had ever done before (at least not well). From just a combination of buttons you can create powerful spells that bare strategy behind them. Of course there are a number of downsides and bugs to this game that when overlooked barely interfere with the gameplay at all and will usually result in a laugh. Make no mistakes, this game is for pure fun and joy.If you are looking for a game to play with your friends then look no further because this game is precisely what you need. You are getting a lot more fun out of this game than the price would intend you to believe. At such a low price you get hours of gameplay excluding all of the tremendous amount of downloadable content. Magicka is a co-op game that brings out the evil inside you and your friends. You can be on your way to defeating the infamous Grimnir when out beaming behind you is a beam of arcane from your companion aiming directly for you. Magicka really brings out the troll in most people and with countless of opportunities to kill you your friends will never get bored killing you and reviving you, killing and reviving you, killing and... yeah.For the serious competitors that don't like the limitations that Magicka: Wizard Wars gives you but are still interested in the humor and game mechanics of Magicka then the pvp or challenge modes will prove to be very effective gamemodes. As stated before Magicka has a very diverse field of strategy. For example someone will be coming at you with some fire so you have to quickly decide to cast a fire shield onto yourself to become immune to fire and then come at them with the most unexpected attacks in order to win a player versus player match. Challenge mode also includes some strategy and competition. Once you die in challenge you're done for and must start from square one. This means you can compete against your friends and see who is the greater wizard.Now I bring you the bugs, glitches and problems this game faces. The bugs in this game are usually hilarious to see happen to someone you are playing with and usually funny to watch when they happen to you. These are the small bugs that don't affect you in a huge way when playing Magicka but through your playthrough it is not unlikely to come across a big glitch that will require you to restart the game and have you go back to the last checkpoint. Another thing that could be considered a problem in this game is it's massive amount of downloadable content which could possibly be a deal breaker for you if you just hate paying just a bit extra for a full package. What I must reassure you with is the fact that none of the extra content is required to feel whole although it is a bit depressing when you look at your robes and see a horde of robes unable to play with. When it comes to actual level and gameplay dlc Paradox have done something I must praise them for. When playing online only the host needs the downloadable content in order to play it so essentially you could play every dlc level without ever paying a cent.This was the first game I had in my library and it's what got me interested in steam. So as someone who has had their lives changed (or ruined from the access to almost every modern pc game developed) I say buy this game whenever you get the chance. If you're interested in humour, magick, wizards, co-op, being a troll, strategic moves, unstrategic fails, using powerful combos that wipes everything off the screen causing you all to go back to the start of the game, competition or vampires that think no one knows that they are vampires then I highly recommend to try this game out regardless if you're a loner and can't find anyone to play it with.

AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Magicka Original Release: 2011 Genre Tags: RPG; Action; Innovative; Lighthearted; Fantasy My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 9-20 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Optional Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Novelty seekers REVIEWMagicka is a very enjoyable game. Fun, funny, and challenging... it makes for a very amusing experience. The standard campaign is relatively brief, but there is a lot of DLC content. Some of it is cosmetic and can be ignored, but much of it provides actual content and you will likely want to pick it up to get the full experience. Magicka also makes for unique and enjoyable multiplayer gameplay, if you find some people to play with. As I alluded to, the innovation inherent in the main gameplay mechanics is the primary reason that Magicka is something worthy of being in your library. There isn’t much else quite like it, and absolutely nothing of the same caliber.  You have to rapidly press certain button combinations to cast various spells while simultaneously controlling your character and aiming in an isometric view. It is pretty unique and intense. I personally found it more comfortable with a controller, but it also works well with a standard keyboard and mouse set up.And while the exciting gameplay is definitely the soul of the game, it is also quite funny and charming too. The art style is very fitting to the mood of the game; and although the graphics aren’t the best, they feel appropriate. With the addition of the mumble language, silly plot, and hyperbole of blood/gore, the jovial nature of Magicka becomes clear. This lighthearted atmosphere synergizes well with the unique gameplay to create an experience that is incontestably fun.The key feature of the game being the innovative gameplay mechanics, I recommend anyone looking for some variety check it out if they haven’t already. I highly recommend playing with other people though; it’s much more fun and much less frustrating (since you can revive each other).Also the Versus and Survival modes are pretty fun, especially since the game supports local-coop (as in sitting on a couch with your friends, as it was in the old days).Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

												Magicka is one of my favorite games, and one of the few that does a good job making you feel like a wizard.The Good:The crown jewel of Magicka's design is its spell creation system.  It was not the first video game to allow you to design spells by selecting the path, area of effect, effects, and intensities.  The Elder Scrolls: Arena had that in 1994, and there may be earlier examples I don't know about.  It may be the first to allow you to create spells on the fly.  It is also noteworthy for having no limits based on a mana pool or cooldowns.  Instead, the main balancing forces are enemy resistances and the destructive power of your own spells.  It's very easy to make a mistake and kill yourself or your allies.Magicka is also well known and loved for its voice acting.  Everyone speaks a mix of broken Swedish and jibberish.  Vlad is an over the top Romanian vampire in denial.  Death and Fafnir also sound great.  I would love to know what sort of processing they performed on their voices.Magicka has one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard.  It's bombastic, complex, and memorable.  Unfortunately it may be hard to appreciate with it often being drowned out by the sounds of the chaos around you.The Bad:Magicka is very buggy, even by modern PC gaming standards.  Crashes and hangs are common.  Weapons and staves, which may be unique, frequently clip through the map and disappear into the void forever.  Players lose connection in online games often.  The DLC is even worse.  The Stars Are Left has an unpatched bug on the last level, where if you don't pass through the doors in the order the developers expected you to, not only does it crash, but it corrupts your save so you have to start that DLC over.  The fact that is still unpatched is shameful, by the way.Difficulty does not scale based on the number of players.  The main game isn't that difficult to get through solo, but some of the DLC is very hard without a full party.  I found the final fights in Dungeons and Daemons and The Stars Are Left to be impossible to solo.

												The 76 metascore is the result of what Magicka was when it came out: A hidden gem executed okey-ishly and with some bugs. But that's way too far from the game Magicka is today...Which is one of the best Local-Multiplayer/Co-Op/Versus games in all of Steam. I was a late buyer so I got to skip all the supposed bug-fest, but let me tell you this: Right now, Magicka is a blast to play with friends. Be it local or online multiplayer, co-op campaign or versus or survival, with keyboards or with controllers or any mix of all of the above. Aside from the super-robust level of multiplayer options, the game's campaigns (main and all of the DLCs) are amazing. The main campaign is filled with easter eggs, little details everywhere and stupendous and magnificent narrative comedy. I'll be frank and admit I haven't finished most DLCs yet (as I wait until all my buds can get together to finish them in one sitting), but I can tell you that The Stars Are Left, The Other Side of the Coin and Dungeons And Daemons are worth every penny.The quality for your money also applies for multiplayer-oriented DLC, which is cheap and adds lots of cool themes, robes with different stats and abilities and weapons that range from The Doctor's Screwdriver to Ak-47s and of course a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amount of staffs.The gameplay is a bit hard to explain as there are truly no games like Magicka: Top down isometric spell casting & mixing shmup with always-on friendly fire is the shortest way to put it. The long one is: You see your wizard from a top-down-with-an-angle perspective, you can cast 8 elements: Fire, Life, Electricity, Water, Cold, Earth, Arcana/Death, and "shield" which gives any combination of elements a defensive use of sorts. All this elements are on their own very weak but once you combine them you can get deadly creative. From mini-volcanoes that light enemies on fire and explode when touched to steam-compressed mines that send foes (and friends) flying away Team Rocket-style to Death-electric beams that freeze to freaking Meteor Showers to casting Death Itself (whom kills someone on-screen at random).Now remember that the game has always-on friendly fire. Yup, it's a madhouse.If Mario Party destroys friendships, Magicka will obliterate blood-related family ties. But in the nicest, funniest and best ways.As a lover of couch co-oping, well-executed games, friendship, and... well, games in general, I urge you, TRY MAGICKA. It's very unlikely you'lle ever regret it.Unless you have no friends, of course. Being burned/electrocuted/bombed-away/exploded into tiny pieces accidentally on purpose is not as much fun when a complete stranger does it.

												I don't think I've ever been so in love with a video game before...It's buggy, horribly optimized, and suffers from such bad models and animations that they make a joke of it (traveling through landscapes that showcase herds of sheep-facades propped up in the pastures, or riding upon noble steeds who seem to be from the finest wooden toy horse stock), and you won't give a damn about any of it.  The multiplayer is nearly impossible to set up and laggy almost to the point of unplayability once you do, but it's such vibrant, stupid and chaotic fun that you'll ignore such minor negatives in favor of the grander scheme of bumbling wizards.The innovative magic system is profoundly complex and joyously destructive to experiment with, and there's a very scientific glee involved with working out your trademark spell(s) or finding the coolest combinations to solve a particular problem.You'll also learn to develop a newfound respect for such veterans of the wizardry craft as Gandalf or Dumbledore...  When you recognize just how much obscenely destructive force you have at your unwitting fingertips, it's always impressive when you DON'T manage to disintegrate/melt yourself and everyone in a 4-mile radius when attempting to do something.While the game is fun enough on its own and the writing is of absolutely stellar class, with actually funny wit and some really quite unexpectedly subtle jokes and twists, this game excels at multiplayer.  Yes, the horribly-irritating-to-get-started multiplayer.My deepest recommendation is to play this game with 3 friends, preferably with none of you knowing your wizard staves from your rump bristles.  Idiocy and a vast array of destructive weaponry often lead to the best of times, and ignorance of your own strength is the perfect excuse for "accidentally" slaughtering everyone on your team.The game starts you off with a resurrection spell, and as with all spells and magic in this game there is neither a mana cost nor a cooldown of any sort...  And you'll be very happy that it is this way, as roughly 98% of player deaths are either self-induced or from friendly fire.  Or some wonderfully flashy combination of the two.Indeed, the greatest danger you face is not the foe in front of you, but rather your overeagerness to simultaneously shock, burn, freeze and meltingly explode the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into his primary colors.  Positively philsophical, really.I have never for a moment regretted purchasing this game.  Indeed, my saddest moment was when it finally ended...  for the second or third time.  Along with all the DLC missions.

												This little gem throws you into the robes of a wizard and sets you on a noble quest to save the world of Midgård from destruction. As a wizard, you are given power over 8 different elements, from which you may cast a vast array of spells by combining them in different ways. This mechanic is very well thought out, with elemental opposites that may or may not result in death if you're not careful, as well as radically different effects for different combinations providing plenty of depth in your spell casting. There are, however, some spell combinations which are obviously more powerful than others, oftentimes leaving no reason to use the others. Despite this, alternate spells do come in handy every once in a while, so don't be afraid to experiment with them.In regards to the story I'm not going to say much so that you can experience it all for yourself, but suffice it to say that it's very much an adventure of epic proportions and theres lots of content to enjoy. Every location and every boss feels unique and is fun to battle. While the adventure is generally supposed to be pretty serious, it's delivered in a silly and lighthearted manner, including humorous narration and funny NPC dialogue. Furthermore, the soundtrack fits in at every moment of the game - it's reminiscent of Lord of the Rings and it's certainly no worse for wear because of it. Booming and powerful when an action scene calls for it, quaint and quiet when it's calm, and with several other tracks to fill in moments of the game that don't quite fit into either category.Finally, there are several modes you can play with your friends and accidentally (read: not really on accident) kill your friends with a spell gone awry or something else. Always great fun to gib your buddies late on a friday night - and yes, if it's not your thing there are settings that change the gore. Magicka Left ArmI believe most gamers know what "Nintendo Thumb" is. For those who don't, it is when you've been been using the D-pad or Gamepad for such a long time that blisters and swellings started to appear on your thumbs or other fingers. Well, having mentioned "Nintendo Thumb", may I introduce a new term to you - the "Magicka Left Arm". This "Magicka Left Arm" is the situation where you've been playing Magicka for such a long time that, when you wake up the very next day, your left arm started to become sore and numb and, in extreme situations such as mine, you cannot move your left arm for the whole day. Yes, this has happened and I shall tell you why.First of all, allow me to begin by describing the game mechanism. It is not wrong to say that this game is based on the concept of conventional Diablo-like RPG. You control a character, nameless and hooded, and you roam around the top-down world by pointing and clicking at locations with your mouse. You are free to run around and whack enemies using your melee weapon, though it is not recommended to do so as you will die like a popcorn. What you can, and should, do is to cast Spells and Magick. Notice how Magick is spelt? It is, of course, different from your typical Diablo-type Magic. In Magicka, Spells and Magicks do not require mana. They are formed and casted based upon 8 different basic elements: Water, Life, Shield, Cold, Lightling, Arcane, Earth and Fire. Each of these elements are bonded to they keys "Q, W, E, R, A, S, D, F" respectively. (There are two advanced elements: Steam and Ice, formed by combining Water + Fire and Water + Ice respectively) You can cast Spells, such as the "Super Steam Lightling Beam" by first pressing the combination "Q, F, Q, F, Q, F, A, S" and then followed by right clicking. In that manner, a strong beam will shoot towards the direction your mouse is pointing towards. There are many others, and you can experiment more with them once you are in game, though I believe this will give you a general concept on spell casting.As for Magicks, they are special magics that can be casted by forming a specific elemental combination and then pressing <space>. For example, if I want to summon an elemental, I will have to press "S, E, D, Q, F, S, <space>". However, one single elemental is too weak and it will be annihilated with in a matter of seconds. So, what did I do? More elementals, of course! After starting the game for a while, I can be seen pressing this elemental summoning sequence repeatedly. I'll be trying to cast 20 or so elementals in a couple of seconds, watch them fight to their deaths while hiding in a shield (opps), and repeat the process. And that, my dear reader, is where I got my "Magicka Left Arm" after 6 hours of game play straight. Don't get me wrong. I am not saying that you have to spam elementals like me. I personally like to take the easy way out, and watching a bunch of kamikaze comandos fight for me can be quite entertaining. There are many other ways to complete the game, and I will give you the liberity to figure it out for yourself. But then and again, you can be quite certain that your left hand will be quite busy throughout the game. This the fun part of the game, and this experience is what make this game worthwhile. The graphics is not much of a looker (look at the screenshots) and the jokes, though initially creative and great, can get quite cheesy in the long run. Great game if you want to enjoy something light and humourous, though watch out for the "Magicka Left Arm". You've been warned - spell casting can be extremely addictive.

This is another very long review. If you just want a summary of my reasons for why I recommend this game skip to Results and read from there.Magicka by Arrowhead Game Studios is an interesting game that really keeps you on your toes. I use the word interesting because this game has some great concepts although I could easily see them as potential weaknesses to some people. Magicka requires you to use physics and chemistry to create spells and solve puzzles. These include such concepts as freezing rivers, powering generators, and combining elements to create powerful spells. The Campaign:You play as one of four wizards who are a part of the Order of Magick. You start their adventure in Castle Alderheim where you are given a quest to save the world. The game includes twelve chapters, which pull you through time and space. You are led by your guide Vlad, possibly a vampire, who continuously points you in the right direction. The campaign requires you to fight many bosses who require different tactics to beat: Jormungandr, Jotunn, The Warlock, Khan, Grimnir, The Aristocrats, Vlad, Death, Fafnir, Grimnir, and Assatur. There are many DLC packs which allow you to play many campaigns and experience a full new game. The campaign has funny dialogue which speaks between English and gibberish. The campaign is rather cut and dry. Each level is essentially the same concept, basically fight the enemies and beat the level. Yet again, this is how most games that fit into this genre seem to be. There are many funny jokes, references, and characters which make this game a blast to play through. In fact one of the Wizards you can select is a Space Marine from the 40k series (plus there are all these game references in the campaign). Gameplay:The enemies tend to repeat themselves and throughout the campaign you typically be using the same spells over again. What most people don’t seem to mention is the difficulty of this game. This game is not easy in any sense of the word, in fact even if you play with more people the game just gets harder. With latency issues and friendly fire can result in a very tough campaign where you will kill your friends more than your enemies. If you play the game solo it can be very difficult and with the patches and updates is even harder now than it was before. There is no mana, no leveling up, and pretty much no real loot. You may find a few weapons throughout the campaign, but they are not going to make a huge difference to how you play the campaign. I personally played the whole game with the M60, but other than that all the weapons seemed to be just as effective as the ones I start with. Useful Advice:Magicka REQUIRES a good keyboard. This keyboard preferably should be a gaming keyboard and should not be wireless (unless it’s a wireless gaming keyboard). In order to preform spells and move at the same time Magicka sometimes requires you to use more keys than you have fingers. If your keyboard cannot handle multiple key-presses then you will not be able to play this game. I would recommend playing this game with a macro-enabled keyboard/mouse in order to fully enjoy the actual campaign. In fact the game can be so difficult that even with macros you will more than likely not succeed in a mission on your first attempt. There are many spell combinations with some of them being very hard to figure out. Results:If you like bird’s eye view co-op action adventures then this could be a good choice for you. Make sure you are well equipped, ready for a hard challenge, and have some friends. This is a fun campaign, with witty dialogue, and amazing spell casting. If you have a great memory for up to eight letter combinations then you’ll be very good at this game. 												In Magicka, you're a wizard. You've got eight elements that you can stack up, mix, multiply, and unleash. You can cast them at goblins, cast them at anything next to you, cast them at your specially blunted sword, cast them at your own face.Singleplayer mode is a light comic fantasy, narrated by your dodgy mentor, Vlad. The black-clad Romanian wizard keeps pointing out that he's not a vampire, and making bad puns about sinking his teeth into things. It's a mix of satire and pop culture references that'll have you smirking dangerously throughout. Lots of care has gone into the way the elements combine and contort in your spells. Combinations shape the form (Missile? Beam? Cone? Wall?) and function (Healing? Burning? Shielding? Exploding? Freezing? Drenching? Zapping?) of each glorious experiment. There's enough variety for every wizard to have his or her own favourite attack style. Mine is a steamy lightning beam that scalds you before dealing bonus lightning damage from the water element in steam.Concocting these spells is a little confusing at first, as you're commanding eight elements across eight keys, but you're rarely faced with enemies that can't be killed by particular elements. Button mashing will get you far, and a mistake might just surprise you. The environments are top-down, linear jaunts through bright and breezy fantasy tropes: forests full of goblins, orcish trenches, swamps, mines, the land of the dead. Wander off the beaten path, and you can find powerful equipment and new magic spell recipes that reach beyond the scope of your regular elemental concoctions - spells such as Revive and Teleport.Singleplayer will soon wear thin, sadly. It's not that you can't beat it with the right spells and an awful lot of goes – it's that if you make a mistake and burst like a sticky water balloon, you get chucked back to the last checkpoint you reached. In once case, that involves fighting three big groups of face-pounding orcs and one-hit-smash-to-deathing ogres, in a row, before you hit another checkpoint. If you quit before you complete that level (perhaps out of, ooh, say, frustration), you'll have to start it all over again when you boot up the game again. Ultimately, you'll hit this annoying boss or that overpowered yeti thing or this boring underworld level and you'll just give up on singleplayer. Then you'll turn to multiplayer. And multiplayer is good, when it works. If you've got a few networked computers and three eager friends with Magicka on their Steam accounts, you can enjoy the splendour of four death lasers combining neatly into a super-beam that bursts ogres in seconds. You can have tactics and gambits and laugh as they end with one wizard left, deciding if he wants your gear before he resurrects you.The bulk of us, however, will be butting our heads against the brick wall of online multiplayer. At the time of writing, developers Arrowhead have been releasing patches every 24 hours, and they're gradually improving on the terrible connectivity issues. Despite their efforts, you no sooner host a game than Steam Chat dies, Skype calls drop, and flatmates start inspecting the router for flashing lights. For a game so reliant on multiplayer to be fun, there are lots of missed opportunities. There's no chapter select function, no joining mid-session for latecomers or disconnected players, no voice chat, no dedicated servers, and tons of lengthy, wordy cutscenes that only the host can skip. Get it working, and it's great. For £8, you'll get your money's worth before everyone forgets about it. But it could have been game of the year material! Silly wizards.THE VERDICT 69/100MAGICKAConfused and buggy, but very entertaining under the right circumstances. Bring friends.

												Imbued with humour and incredibly fun, Magicka is one of the best co-op games I played, despite its occasional random crashes and bugs. The best thing about it is its spell-casting system that allows players to create spells on the fly and encourages them to experiment. While there are a couple of dozen predefined spells ("magicks") in the form of spellbooks that need to be discovered throughout the game to be used, most of the time players will be using spells of their own design, creating them by combining any of the 8 different elements (water, life, shield, frost, lightning, arcane, earth and fire). Some elements cancel each other out, while other can be combined to make new elements (water + fire makes steam, for example, which can be combined with lightning to increase damage as lightning will do more damage to enemies that are made wet by steam). There is no mana or similar system in Magicka so there are no limitations to how many spells can be cast in a row, and the combat is fast paced. If you play with friends  you'll probably occasionally kill them or get killed by them. Their earth projectile will accidentally bounce off your head or you'll lock beams and explode or you'll be struck by a wayward lightning bolt while your friend is off to the side pretending that he wasn't casting anything and that he's not right now ransacking your bloodied corpse to steal your gear.... It is all part of the game, and half of the time it's what makes Magicka so much fun to play with friends. Just remember: W+A is Revive but you cannot cast it while wet because you'll die. Like I did. (Many times.)In addition to the hilariousness of the random self- or friend-inflicted deaths, there's also a lot of humour in the story. The NPCs speak a sort of gibberish version of Swedish which sounds comically silly (even more so if you speak Swedish, I'm told) and the story is riddled with pop-cultural references. Theme-wise, it's standard RPG fare: you are a wizard trying to save the world, fighting goblins, orcs, dragons, even Death. If it weren't for the fact that it is also frequently buggy, Magicka would be outstanding. Unfortunately, the game has a tendency to randomly crash in loading screens or during cut-scenes, it occasionally bugs out so that you can't move during a boss fight, and match-making can be iffy. In addition, the game does not allow to skip through all cut-scenes, which can get tedious if you are repeatedly redoing a boss fight, and I was personally annoyed by some design choices – specifically the fact that "examining" a statue prevents you from casting anything for a few seconds while the dialogue plays out, but several huge statues with huge 'hitboxes' were placed in an area littered with enemies and hazards, as a result of which I was getting killed because simply going near the statues would trigger the "examine" action and I could not do anything to avoid damage.These minor frustrations mar what is otherwise a great game, but Magicka is nevertheless an incredibly fun co-op experience.

												Magicka is a game where you are a wizard, trying to conjure spells using elements. The catch is that multiple combinations yield multiple spells, most of which will severely injure yourself and your teammates. The goodYou are given from start, after a quick tutorial on the basics, all the elements. This allows you to beat the game with anything.Combining elements is the key factor of the game, where you can cast a stone armor to protect yourself and lay healing mines for your teammate who crushes enemies using a steam-electric-arcane beam. Without a mana or cooldown system.there are some hidden goodies to look for, some only for the sake of it, like the mooses, or magicks, a spell that has to be entered in the right order.Magicks are unlockable combinations that are far more powerful and/or unique than your normal spells. From slowing time to freezing the entire screen, or as simple as a teleport of flammable oil. They serve the purpose of progression, and one is even a plot point of the game.The game is also a living pile of references, ranging to movies to games. If you like to see that kind of stuff, it's plenty in this game.The badThe plot is simple: Your goal is to defeat the main wizard baddie. No heavy plot twists or anything.The game is also filled with bugs, bust most of them are fixed within seconds. Gamebreaking bugs can be fixed with an easy restart, which will take you a few screens back. The netcode tend to be laggy for the clients, even with low ping.Most player characters are DLC, but most of them are simple reskins with no unbalanced stats. Some extra content are also DLC-only. The ugly  Sometimes the physics are wonky, with the knockback being powerful enough to knock your wizard several meters in the air. You can even reach spots you weren't meant to this way.Friendly-fire is also a key factor in the game, which can get problematic in certain situations, such as in tight spaces or a miscast. Hilarity can ensue if the wonky physics kick in.There may or may not be some plot holes around. Not that relevant, since the plot is already an excuse to cast stuff around.Some bosses can be one-shotted. While some can provide a worthwhile fight, some can be downed in seconds. However, one-shotting a boss requires some skill (and luck), and can be satisfying if you did it right.NutshellGrab this game if you got the coin and friends to play with. I still haven't played through all the chapters and DLC-content, but the fun-factor I had playing with my friend is undeniable. 												Magicka is a mostly cooperative (friendly fire is on) game about combining elements to create magic spells. It supports up to 4 player multiplayer with a adventure, challenge, and versus mode. The way the magic spells work is you have 6 slots to put elements in, and whatever combination you put in is mixed to create a unique spell. There are literally unlimited spell combinations, so there's tons of diversity. There's also books scattered around where you can find these things called Magicks, these are pre-set spells that do special things (some notable ones are summons, vortex, rain/thunderstorm/blizzard, ect). There are also many robes you can select aswell, they have special perks and downsides that make them unique from eachother (like immunity/weakness to some elements). The campaign could last you a good 4-5 hours with added DLC campaigns as well to add on to it. There are A LOT of DLC for this game, mostly PVP maps and robes, these are NOT needed and you should only get them if you feel like you would like those robes/maps or want to support the developer but the campaign DLCs are a must have in my opinion. People say this game is a buggy mess, and it is, but the glitches you may encounter are actually entertaining. The developer have worked hard and patched out most of the game ruining ones, so there's not much to worry about. Get this game, it's worth your money if you have friends to play it with.

Intro: This is a game that really benefited from having a demo. I enjoyed it so much while trying it out that I stopped and purchased it.The game can be fun alone, but I highly really recommend multiplayer for this one. Host your own room and play through the story while people drop in and out. If you have a few gamepads and friends you can also play locally on the same PC. Its a ton of fun either way.Gameplay: Magicka's gameplay is pretty entertaining. It has a neat magic system with lots of possibilities and a bunch of weapons you can come across. Loads of different characters. A bunch of game modes. A few different campaigns, some mini-campaigns, pvp arenas, and survival maps. Every mode is great fun to play and there's really a ton of content here. Just playing random multiplayer games can be a blast.Music & Visuals: The music was fitting, but nothing too memorial. The production was good nonetheless. I liked the artstyle. It was pretty and you can turn the gore off if that bothers you or if someone younger is going to play with you. Looks pretty nice overall.Story: The story was solid. Each campaign has its own. Its not really anything special, but its something there and gives you a goal.PC Version: Game runs pretty fine for the most part.I remember extremely high pings would cause multiplayer to crash. This may have been fixed as it was many years back, but as long as everyone was under 200ms then I didn't run into problems. Gamepads work fine with the game, though kb+m is a bit easier.One thing that some may not like - Magicka is one of those games with way too much DLC, but there's still a lot in the default game. Your best bet is buying the full bundle though during a large discount in a sale. I know some people can't stand loads of DLC, but it actually adds quite a lot without being too pricey.Conclusion: Overall its a fun game to play and has a lot of replay value. Go for it, especially if you have some friends to play with. My hours on the game are somewhat low, but its definitely something I'd play again if any of my friends were ever interested.

Oh this brave Macjika world, that has such goblins in it...Okay, enough with the waxing lyrical. Majicka is a game desinged for four players, all of which are extremely squishy wizards with godlike powers, to play online or through Lan. Of course it isn't designed for nothing BUT online play, as Majicka does allow for single player, and in many cases it may be easier by yourself as you can unleash the full fury of your wizardly prowress without worrying about making that red wizard you just met five minutes ago dissapear in a flash of light, a thunderclap, and massive damage.Majicka is, of course, about magic, and magic is surprisingly easy to use, and hard to master. You are given eight elements to mix and match, some of which do cancel each other out, I should mention, and depending on how you use these elements depends on what happens. Cast the Lighting spell by pressing q f a s a to prepeare the elements, then spacebar to use these elements to complete a recipie that allows you to rain down death on anyone stupid enought to anger you, stand in front of you, or stand slightly to the left or right of you (seriously, you can't aim that spell for ♥♥♥♥). This game is smart enought to know that refrences are not the same as humour, and as such simply makes the refrences clever instead of rubbing your face in it and expecting you to laugh.Of course, it does have a few bugs. From the start of the game you are given access to all 8 elements (water, life, shield, cold, fire, earth, arcane, and lighting) which can be combined for various effects. Each element affects the area differently depending on the form and combination. if you use it in its direct form (some are spray, earth is projectile, and others are beam) it is mainly a attack. if  you use say, earth + shield, on yourself it creates a body armor. If you use the same combination directly it surrounds you with a rock wall. If you use it as an Area of Effect it causes a small earthquake around your character. And if you enchant your melee weapon with it the weapon will also vary the effect.
